did.head: Collection Overview
did.langmaterial: Collection material is music with accompanying notes in English and vocal texts in English and French.

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: State University of New York at Buffalo. Music Library

did.abstract: The Livingston Gearhart Collection of Scores contains compositions and arrangements by Gearhart in published and manuscript forms, as well as sketches and incomplete works. It also contains published scores by other composers annotated by Gearhart.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Specified item], Livingston Gearhart Collection of Scores, 1930-1996, Music Library, The State University of New York at Buffalo.

accessrestrict.head: Terms of Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials can be examined by qualified researchers in the Music Library during hours of operation during which Music Librarians are present. In order to insure access, researchers are advised to contact the Music Library in advance of visits.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: Copyright for the materials in the collection does not reside with the Music Library. Therefore, patrons wishing to publish any item, or part of an item from this collection for any purpose, are responsible for securing requisite permissions.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Livingston, Pamela, and Fritz Gearhart.

accruals.head: Accruals and Additions
accruals.p: No further accruals are expected to this collection.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Kathryn M. Blough, 1999; re-processed by Jared Rex, 2011-2012. Additions processed by John Bewley, 2018.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Livingston Gearhart was born in Buffalo, New York December 31, 1916. His mother was Lillian Hawley Gearhart, a pianist who had studied for a year under Theodor Leschetizky in Vienna. As a child Gearhart studied piano, oboe, violoncello, and sang in church choirs in Buffalo and New York City. He graduated from high school in East Orange, New Jersey in 1935. He entered Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia in 1935 as an oboe student of Marcel Tabuteau. In his second year he switched his major to study composition with Rosario Scalero and piano with Nadia Reisenberg.

Gearhart sailed to Paris aboard the Normandie in 1937. With generous support from a wealthy American expatriate, he was able to enroll at the Conservatoire Américain de Fontainebleau where he studied music theory and composition with Nadia Boulanger. He was awarded the school's 2nd prize (no first prize was awarded that year) in the Prix Stovall composition competition in 1937. While in Paris he also met Igor Stravinsky, Darius Milhaud, Robert Casadesus, pianist Isidore Philipp, and his future wife and duo-piano partner, Virginia Clotfelter. He and Virginia performed their debut in Paris February 1, 1939 at the Salle Chopin. They received good reviews and were then able to give concerts in other French and Swiss locations until the conditions of World War II caused them to return to the United States.

Virginia Clotfelter adopted the professional name Morley and married Gearhart February 28, 1940 in New York City. They worked at numerous venues, including the Hotel Brevoort and the club, Ruban Bleu, both operated by Herbert Jacoby. The pair spent the summers of 1942 and 1943 as Artists-in-Residence at Morley's alma mater, Mills College in Oakland, California. While there Gearhart was able to study composition with Darius Milhaud. The Budapest String Quartet was also in residence at Mills College during those years and Gearhart and Morley formed friendships with quartet members Alexander and Mischa Schneider. The Morley Gearhart duo was very successful, performing works by Milhaud, Norman Dello Joio, David Diamond, and Stravinsky's Concerto per due pianoforte soli.

The duo received contracts with Columbia Concerts and the Fred Waring Show that extended from 1943-1954. During 1941 to 1954, the two-piano team of Morley and Gearhart performed over 2000 concerts throughout the US and Canada in addition to recording for Columbia Masterworks and Decca Records. Included among the many concert dates was a performance by the duo at the White House for President Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1953. During this period Gearhart also worked as a staff arranger for the Fred Waring Show.

A two-CD retrospective released in 2001, Morley and Gearhart Rediscovered by Ivory Classics, features 22 of Gearhart's two-piano arrangements. Some of these arrangements survive at Penn State in their collection, Fred Waring's America. In many cases Gearhart never fully wrote out his part of a duo so no written arrangement survives.

Livingston Gearhart's output contains several collections written for pedagogical purposes. The first of Gearhart's these works to be published was Clarinet Sessions in 1945. That was followed by similar collections for trumpet, violin, flute, and duos. Gearhart's entire compositional and arranging output includes 400-500 works (counting individual works within the collections).

Gearhart returned to Buffalo in 1955 and was appointed to the faculty of the music department at the University of Buffalo. After a divorce from Virginia Morley, he married violinist and conductor Pamela Gerhart (not a misspelling) in 1955. He taught various courses in keyboard, theory, and orchestration until his retirement in 1985.
Livingston Gearhart had four children: Paul, born to Virginia Morley Gearhart; Kim, Martha, and Fritz, born to Pamela Gearhart. Livingston Gearhart died in Buffalo at the age of 79 on July 14, 1996.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection contains 676 folders. As part of the original collection, there are 257 folders containing manuscript and published scores of Livingston Gearhart’s compositions and arrangements, 79 folders containing published scores by other composers annotated for performance by Gearhart, and 5 folders containing sketchbooks or workbooks with various musical exercises, sketches, and other works. Excluding the annotated scores and the scores added after original processing was completed, there are approximately 178 folders containing manuscript materials and 84 folders containing printed materials. Of the printed works, approximately 69 were published by Shawnee Press. Gearhart composed his works between 1930 and 1996 but five of his compositions in the collection were published after his death in 1997. His son Fritz Gearhart and wife Pamela Gearhart did extensive work to organize materials and edited several for publication.

The manuscript scores document Gearhart’s work from sketches through different versions to the finished, final version of a work. Most of these are in Gearhart’s hand with a small percentage being copied by other people. Many of the scores are accompanied by instrumental parts and explanatory notes of varying lengths by either Livingston,Pamela, or Fritz Gearhart. These notes often provide details about the background and history of works.

A major component of Gearhart’s output consists of his approximately 119 arrangements. These include arrangements chiefly made for didactic purposes for various instrumental combinations, arrangements for two pianos, many of which were used by Gearhart in his performances with Virginia Morley during their years as a piano-duo, choral arrangements, and arrangements for band or orchestra. There are other works by Gearhart that are difficult to classify strictly as arrangements due to the extent of Gearhart’s compositional reworking of the material. The titles identified as arrangements draw from a wide range of sources, including works by composers such as Arlen, Bach, Berlioz, Boccherini, Brahms, Brubeck, Debussy, Delius, Fauré, Johann Fischer, Haydn, Holst, J. Rosamond Johnson, Joplin, Lyadov, Macdowell, Mendelssohn, Mozart, Cole Porter, Serge Prokofiev, Purcell, Rachmaninoff, Ravel, Rimsky-Korsakov, Schubert, Stravinsky, and Wolf-Ferrari in addition to traditional and popular tunes such as We wish you a merry Christmas, Star spangled banner, Non nobis, Domine, and Au clair de la lune.

Gearhart’s pedagogical works include several compilations that consist of both original and arranged works. Most of these are in a series he titled Sessions: Bass Clef Sessions, Clarinet Sessions, Duet Sessions, Fiddle Sessions, Flute Sessions, Rhythm Sessions, Sax Sessions, Treble Clef Sessions, and Trumpet Sessions. Six of these titles were published by Shawnee Press. Many of the pieces within the compilations were written to provide practice in specific rhythmic and technical elements. Gearhart also devised sets of trick pieces and canons to assist with teaching. Another aspect of Gearhart’s pedagogical work is evident in the many pieces he arranged for use by his wife, Pamela Gearhart, in her work as conductor of the orchestra of the Community Music School of Buffalo and numerous string workshops and musical clinics, including a summer music camp in Huntsville, Alabama called Youth Makes Music. Gearhart also composed a set of nine pieces titled Extraits de mon cahier for pedagogical use by his teacher at Curtis Institute of Music, Marcel Tabuteau.

In addition to separate musical sketches, the collection also contains twelve sketchbooks or workbooks containing original compositions and arrangements as well as studies in harmony and counterpoint written while Gearhart was studying in Paris with Nadia Boulanger. An item of interest is a workbook titled Quodlibets research. It includes a comparative table containing chord structures of various pieces from the folk song, popular, and classical music repertoire. Another item of special interest is a sketchbook containing a two-piano arrangement of Mozart's Quintet in E-flat major K. 614. According to a note by Gearhart the arrangement is by pianist Robert Casadesus and was copied by Virginia Morley.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in six series:

item.ref: II. Arrangements, transcriptions, and editions of works by other named composers

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by main entry (composer or title). Compositions by Gearhart are under his name alphabetically in the list and then arranged alphabetically by uniform title. Folk song arrangements are listed by the uniform title for the specific song. There are two other composers stated in the list, Philip Klein and Virginia (Morley) Waring. Gearhart was co-composer of both pieces. Those works are stated under the respective composer's name: Klein and Waring. Sketches of untitled or unidentified works are listed under Gearhart's name and then under titles beginning with the word unidentified or untitled.

scopecontent.p: The series includes arrangements of works such as folksongs and spirituals not attributed to a single composer. It also includes musical sketches of both complete and incomplete works, with and without titles.

scopecontent.p: Contents: Lament : woodwind quintet (Gargenville 1937) -- Motet : woodwind quintet ("Revision for woodwinds, Mills College, 1941") -- Mésures sur la France ("for André Maurois, Mills, July 26, 42") -- Dialogue for 2 oboes (Aug. 42) -- Kitsch : 2 flutes (Aug. 42) -- Untitled : 2 oboes (Aug. 42) -- Dance for 2 flutes (Sept. 42) -- Epitaph (I) : flute (Orinda Sept. 42) -- Prelude (1) : cello and piano (Wilsonia Sept.42) -- Revision of Prelude, for string orchestra, is filed loose in the same envelope. Revision titled Short Suite (see note included) -- Grave : viola, accompaniment (Orinda Sept. 42) -- Lament : 3 oboes (Orinda Sept. 42) -- Fanfare : 3 oboes (Sept. 42) -- Invention : 2 oboes (Denver, Nov. 1942) -- Soliloquoy : oboe alone (May 43) -- Song without words II (Now I lay me down to sleep) : for English horn, 2 clarinets, 2 bassoons ("for N.B.") (1941) -- Madrigal : 2 oboes (Mar. 26, 43) -- Forlana : oboe (Apr. 3, 43) -- Sonata : 2 oboes (Orinda Sept. 42) -- Canon al novescio (sp. rovescio?) ("a canonic problem") : 2 unidentified instruments (Denver, Nov. 1942) -- "Reminiscence of Ravel in 2nd phrase and last" : 2 unidentified instruments (So. Orange Dec. 42) -- "A problem in form" : 2 unidentified instruments (N.Y. Apr. 9, 44) -- Fragment : 2 oboes -- Song without words (I) : 2 clarinets, horn or bassoon, bassoon (July 3, 1944) -- Orientale : violin and harpsichord ("for A.S.") ("6/30/44 II; piece for Merce Cunningham 1/6/45 III") (see note about dedication to Alexander Schneider) -- Child's piece : 2 unidentified instruments (1/12/45) -- Russian dance : 4 trumpets ("dedicated to Igor Stravinsky") (½8/45).

note.p: Alternate title: American sketch.
Alternate title: Baby boogie.

scopecontent.p: Contents: [Flight of the bumblebee / Rimsky-Korsakov -- March from The love of three oranges] / Prokofieff -- American sketch : [unfinished] -- [Viennese clock : from Háry János] / Kodaly -- In dir ist Freude / [Johann Sebastian Bach] -- Baby boogie -- Star spangled banner -- [My country 'tis of thee -- La Marseillaise -- Untitled].

scopecontent.p: Contents: For two players. Air for two viols / Francois Couperin. Andante from Sonata (Köchel No. 292) / Mozart. Arkansas traveler. Chinese lullaby. Fugue un A B-A-D E-G-G / Egon Toast. Gavotte / Dumont. Good King Wenceslas. Habanera / Pierre Vivant. Hare and tortoise / Aesop. Hark, the herald angels sing / Mendelssohn. In the cool cellar. Jazz on rye / Chateau. MinueteuniM / Al. Rovescio. "Mixed metre" / Mozart. Passacaglia / Raimondi. Phantasm / Prokofieff. Preludelerp / J.S. Bach. Rondo from Sonata (Köchel No. 292) / Mozart. Sarabande. Sicilienne. Sinfonia / Webbe. Song of the vulgar boatman / Deranged. We three kings of Orient are / Hopkins -- For three players. Andante from Sonata, op. 26 / Beethoven. Fanfare for the hunt / Pierre Vivant. Fanfare for a procession / Claude Debussy. Gagliarda / Kuhnau. Good King Wenceslas. Hark, the herald angels sing / Mendelssohn. Little brown jug / W.H. Madrigal / Palestrina. March / Handel. Marche from "The love for three oranges" / Prokofieff. Marche Funebre / Chopin. Nocturne from "A midsummer night's dream" / Mendelssohn. Northern song / Schumann. Now the day is over / Barnby. Round on the name B-A-C-H / Beethoven. Sweet and low / Barnby. Three rounds for three. Presto / Haydn. Lacrimosa / Schubert. Roundhouse blues / Devinez. Under this stone lies Gabriel John / Purcell. Waltz Glissando. We three kings of Orient are / Hopkins. Wild horsemen / Schumann -- For four players. Auld lang syne. Base, vile blues / Devinez. Elegie / Massenet. Equali No. 1 / Beethoven. Etude / Schumann. Fanfare for a procession / Claude Debussy. Hunting song / Brahms. In memoriam / Schubert. Misspelled music. Now thank we all our God / harm. J.S. Bach. Now the day is over / Barnby. O sacred head, now wounded / harm. J.S. Bach. Prayer / Cesar Franck. Ricercare / Gabriele Fattorini. Riffin' a round. Round for four / Brahms.

note.p: Chiefly examples of harmonic progressions presented in textbook format with assignments. Topics covered include music fundamentals, 6/4 chords, the use of scale degree 7 in V7 chords, and realizing chords from figured bass. Livingston Gearhart presumably took these notes and used these exercises with Nadia Boulanger in Paris between 1937-1940. Title supplied by cataloger. Holograph (Ink).
Text in English.

arrangement.p:
Arranged into two subseries:
A. Compositions
B. Arrangements

scopecontent.p: Scores were received after the processing of the original collection was completed. Materials were received from Norma Jean Lamb, former music librarian of the Buffalo and Erie County Library, and the estate of Livingston Gearhart. Materials include original compositions by Livingston Gearhart, arrangements for two pianos and orchestra created for use by the Gearhart-Morley piano duo, a collection of string trio arrangements chiefly created for use of Gearhart's son, violinist Fritz Gearhart, arrangements for orchestra and other larger instrumental ensembles, and many shorter arrangements created for use in various pedagogical contexts.
Contains works composed by Livingston Gearhart and one work possibly written or transcribed by his mother, Lillian Hawley Gearhart.

Gearhart – Prelude #4 / Chopin – Pastorale / Stravinsky – Pavane of the sleeping beauty / M. Ravel – Iste confessor – Greensleeves – Bouree I and II / J.S. Bach – We wish you a merry Christmas – God rest ye … -- First noel – Good King W. – We 3 kings – Silent night – Bachianas Buffalonis -- Auld lang syne – Antiques refinished (the series) [Minuet in G major] – Variations on a British air / by Livingston Gearhart, edited by Fritz Gearhart – Ala fanfare, for horn, trumpet, and string orchestra – Kyrie for string orchestra / by Livingston Gearhart – Short suite for string orchestra / by Livingston Gearhart.

Arrangements made for use in pedagogical compilations and settings. After Livingston Gearhart's death, Pamela and Fritz Gearhart continued to edit many of the works for possible publications. Their correspondence and markings are included.

For string duos, trios, and quartets.

Received in a folder marked YMM for Youth Makes Music, the music camp run by Pamela and Livingston Gearhart in Huntsville, Alabama, 1972-1981. The music was written and arranged to serve the pedagogical purposes of the camp instruction for string players. Portion of folder marked with contents inserted in first folder.

otherfindaid.head: Additional Guides
otherfindaid.p: Scores in Series I-III in the collection are cataloged in WorldCat and are available in the online catalog for the University at Buffalo Libraries by performing a "Title begins with" search under "Livingston Gearhart Collection of Scores".

relatedmaterial.head: Related Resources in the Music Library

defitem.label: Livingston Gearhart Papers, 1933-1997 Mus. Arc. 23.1
defitem.item: Collection contains prose writings, vitae, correspondence, teaching materials, programs, and clippings.

defitem.label: Livingston Gearhart Collection of Photographs,1896-1941 Mus. Arc. 23.3
defitem.item: Collection of 192 images, including photographs of Nadia Boulanger and her summer class of 1938, Gearhart and his first wife, Virginia Morley (Waring) at Mills College in California, with composer Darius Milhaud and his family, and the Budapest String Quartet. The collection also includes four photographs of composer Johannes Brahms in 1896. Also available as a digital collection in University Libraries Digital Collections.

defitem.label: Livingston Gearhart Recordings, 1949-2001 Mus. Arc. 23.4
defitem.item: Collection of 23 recordings, including compositions and arrangements by Livingston Gearhart, his memorial service, and the recordings of duo-pianists, Morley and Gearhart.
Pennsylvania State University's collection of Fred Waring's music, including some of Livingston Gearhart's arrangements.

defitem.label: Boulanger, Nadia. Scores by American Composers: A Guide.Ms. Coll. 125
defitem.item:
This collection in the Eda Kuhn Loeb Music Library at Harvard University contains five manuscript scores for Livingston Gearhart original compositions.
Piece for Aaron Copland for flute, clarinet, English horn, bassoon, violin, and viola
Prière for "voix d'enfant" and string quartet
Danse russe. Hommage à Igor Stravinsky for 4 trumpets
O Emmanuel for chorus and piano
Rorate coeli for chorus and piano
